TopicTitle: Would you ride your own rocket?

Articles.Content:
Lets say for a minute that KSP was real and was scaled up in size to fit a person. You design the first rocket and have the opportunity to ride it on its very first launch.

No quicksaves or reloads allowed.

Do you go for the ride?
If there is a more qualified person behind the weel because my brain would explode
Only if I can ride my Eeloo rocket.

Yes.

10characters

Absolutely. I design all of my rockets to be safe and I never let Kerbals in them until they've been proven reliable.

-Slashy
yup, but by god would i test the .... out of it
I would go in my rockets, yes. But only the safest ones.
I would go in rockets, but only the ones I have that are reliable and safe.

As a newbie that just tried the free version? NO, with the experience I have now I would fly one of my own design for sure. I would be more worried about flying in one of Elon Musk's but I would do it. However I regularly do things where I have to have confidence in my ability (skiing, boarding, scrambling in the mountains with serious exposure).

I would gladly fly my own rockets, and even pay for the opportunity to do so. The success rate of all my rockets is very near 100%, with assorted safety features and escape systems if anything goes wrong. There is also an "restricted inclination" and a "restricted altitude", which my spacecraft cannot pass or face legal reprecussions. This ensures that if any manned vessel breaks down, it is within range of a spacestation or one of its RCS tugs to reach and bring them back to the station to await a shuttle to bring them home. Even on beyond LKO-missions, the craft are loaded with extra fuel and supplies in case of emergencies, and there is a spacestation around the Mun and a small surface outpost to host anyone whos stranded. Travel for non-Expedition missions is pretty limited to within range of a base or station, and it is sort of restricting and highly inefficent (I still haven't been to all the Mun or Minimus biomes yet), but to this day, not a single Kerbal has been lost in space under my watch.

And I'm proud of that

Edited August 3, 2014 by NASAFanboy

Seeing as I'm a human, not a Kerbal, I'd have quite a task of riding in one of their rockets. They're not even 1 meter tall, you realize! But if I were a Kerbal, I wouldn't have any hesitation about riding one of my rockets. They're all pretty darn stable, and have reasonable margin-of-error fuel levels. Might be a bit leery of some of my larger spaceplanes, though. Even when they do have rock-solid CoM/CoL from start to finish, they also tend to have too little lift for their mass and are thus very hard to land safely.

Edited August 3, 2014 by SkyRender
Hell no!!!!
Considering most of my designs are based off of real life rockets with a proven track record, yes.

After reviewing the original question, I've got to change my answer to no, Hell no.

Nobody rides one of my rockets until I've had a chance to torture test it unmanned and prove it safe, and that includes me.

HECK YEAH!

If somebody else was onboard...

Ditto.

It wouldn't be Kerbal if there wasn't some chance (read that as HUGE) of explosions
I'd put my seat belt on an hour before launch.

I would likely do so, though I'd definitely want to test it extensively before launching. Additionally, I'm not as worried about the rocket exploding on ascent (my ships are usually fairly safe), but g-forces. I tend to follow the 'moar power is moar better' mantra for upper stages, so I wind up with a high thrust engine, exacting the kerbals inside to fairly high forces. I'd definitely switch out for a lower-thrust engine if I was to ride one of my designs.
Only if I somehow manage to make it safe
NO. Period
Considering my rockets only explode on launch about 50% - 75% of the time... sure!
Darn right I would. My rockets are safe, reliable, and cushy.

Its been about a month since the last time one of my rockets exploded (unless it was my piloting skills).

Short answer: YES!
My crew capsule ones sure. My station launch ones? Not a chance.

Considering that none of my rockets are designed with enough delta-V to achieve LEO, no, I would certainly not.
